funFacts.title: No Word for 'Translator'
funFacts.description: In Ancient Greek, there wasn't a specific word for 'translator.' The closest term was διερμηνεύς, meaning 'interpreter,' which mostly referred to spoken mediation. It's fascinating how language evolution reflects cultural priorities and communication methods.

funFacts.title: Bilingual Rosetta Stone
funFacts.description: The Rosetta Stone is the earliest known bilingual 'translation memory' involving Greek. Created in 196 BCE, it features Greek, Demotic, and Hieroglyphs. This monumental inscription played a crucial role in deciphering Egyptian scripts, showcasing the power of multilingual documents.
